name: Aarav
comment info: I noticed that before 1921, when Congress took advantage of a fixed share of national- origin born people, the population of foreign-born people decreased rapidly. name: Allison Coble
comment info:
When I first looked at this graph, I noticed the effect that quotas had on the fluctuation of populations, but never realized the math and algebra behind the graph until I read the reveal. The heat map shows statistically the changes in populations per state through formulas, which is represented by colors. The darker green represents an increase in immigration, while the purple represents a decrease in immigration. The differentiation in shades of green, are changes in percentages of population. 

Overall, I was very surprised by the reveal and how it related to the statistics, which mathematicians uncovered. My only question is how did they create these formulas and methods which they use now?

comment info: I had noticed that in 1921, congress imposed national-origin quotas, and in 1965 President Lyndon B. Johnson ended quotas. name: Grace R
comment info: The first graph shows how the share of the foreign-born population has changed over time based on the region of origin. Prior to 1921, a significant majority of the immigrant population was European. In 1921, however, Congress imposed national-origin quotas. These policy changes seemed to drastically lower the number of new immigrants, and diversified them slightly. In 1965, President LBJ ended these quotas and immigration rose. After the 1970s, the percentage of immigrants that were European drastically shrunk and Latin American immigrants became the most common. I wonder what caused the immigration quotas to be passed and later repealed, and if there are any concerns over quotas currently. The second graph shows how the immigrant population has changed in each county across America. There seems to be less growth in the northernmost parts of the country, and the most growth in the southeast and midwest. I wonder what has caused these changes and why most immigrants are settling there. One possible title for these graphs would be “Immigration Fluctuations in the U.S.”

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Grace R Great explanation

name: Evan Peña
comment info:
The first thing I noticed was that the largest percent change of foreign born share of the population in 1990-2017 was concentrated in North Carolina/Virginia, which was surprising. I was almost certain it would either be in Texas or somewhere like New York. 
      I am curious about why the change is concentrated in these areas, all I could think of would be lots of available jobs in these regions. I also noticed that the change began increasing when the quotas based on national origin were ended. 
       Another reason that the foreign born people are concentrated in the Eastern states could be that there are more big cities on the east coast, providing more opportunities for them to make a living.

replies.comment info:
Good afternoon, @Evan Peña --

Great wondering about why there is so much growth in foreign-born population in North Carolina and Virginia.  Maybe, as you say, it's that there are jobs there.  Or, maybe it's because there were very few foreign-born there up until now.  

How about where you live?    You can look on the map or search online for the data.

name: Paulo
comment info: I noticed that from 1880 to around 1950 most of the foreign-born population was composed of Europeans, but in 1921, when the congress imposed natural-origin quotas the level of foreign-born europeans started to decrease. The other foreign-born nationalities stayed relatively the same. It wasn't until 1965, when president Lyndon B. ended the quotas that the Latin America levels and the Asia levels of foreign born people increased. The Europe levels kept going down.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Paulo --

The European foreign-born share of the population has been decreasing but has the number of European foreign-born decreased?  If you do some searching online, I bet you could find out.

replies.name: E
replies.comment info: @Paulo Yes, I noticed that as well and was surprised that Europe levels consistently decreased over time. I believe President Lyndon B. ending quotas had a large impact on Latin America and Asia levels increasing greatly.

name: Moderator
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs: “The Rise and Fall of Foreign-Born Groups Over Time” by Brennan of Seattle, "The History and Dispersion of Foreign-Born Groups in America" by Erin of Oregon, “A Change in the Nation's face” by Ava of Ohio, and "How Laws Change a Whole Population” from Juan Jorge of the American School Foundation of Guadalajara in Mexico.
 
You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow, Thursday afternoon, May 7, to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and a few Stat Nuggets.

The next graph will be released in two days, Friday, May 8, with moderation on Wednesday, May 13.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to “What's Going On In This Graph?”  The graph – timeline for coronavirus vaccines.  Stay tuned.

You can see all of the released graphs on the “What’s Going On In This Graph?” homepage.  Or, search for our post “Looking for Graphs to Use in the Classroom? Here Are 34.” for an index by context and an index by type of graph. 

The link for the Stat Nuggets archives ishttps://tinyurl.com/StatNuggets.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney of Boston, whose grandparents came to the United States just before the percipitious dip in foreign born, and Annie Fetter of Rutledge, Pennsylvania, whose great-grandparents all came to the U.S. from Europe in the late 1800s.

name: Graceanna
comment info:
The graph shows that prior to imposing national-origin quotas in 1921, there was an increase/steady amount of immigrants in the United States; after Congress imposed them, there was a great decrease until Lyndon B Johnson ended them. It's interesting to see how the vast majority of immigrants were Europeans, and how that started to decrease, and now the majority of immigrants are Latin Americans or Asians. The reason there were so many European immigrants pre and during 1920s was because many of them were leaving their countries to come live and work in the United States, being sold to the idea of the American Dream (ie Ellis Island). I wonder why the majority immigrant group has shifted to Latin Americans and Asians. 

Title: "There's No Place like Home"

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Graceanna.  I wondered that same thing about why the immigrants are now coming from different places. I thought of a lot of reasons, but will have to do some reading to learn more!

I wonder what you thought of the map by county. Was there anything interesting for you? Did you notice anything about the counties that are closest to you?

name: Juan Pablo
comment info: I noticed that in 1921 the year where the congress imposed national-origin quotas, It went down 10% down to 5% But something I also noticed is that when President Lyndon B Johnson ended quotas based on national origin in 1965 he finished the decrease and it started increasing again up to almost the same as before 1921

replies.comment info: Hi, @Juan Pablo.  Isn't it interesting that it's about back to the 1921 levels?  What did you think of the origins of the foreign-born folks and how that has changed from 1921?

name: Lauren T
comment info: This graph and map show immigrants’ share of the United States population. The top graph is the foreign-born share of the US population changing over time by region of origin. I noticed that when Congress imposed national-origin quotas it had a huge effect on the percentage of foreign-born share of the population. When President Lydon B Johnson ended quotas based on national origin in 1965 numbers began to increase a great amount. In the map below I noticed that foreign-born people moved to the easter part of the United States. I wonder why it took so long for the quotas to be ended?

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren T. I wondered why it took so long for the quotas to be ended, too, and I look forward to doing some research about that.

In the map, I was thinking about the fact that many of the counties that are now dark green might not have had many foreign-born folks living there.  If three foreign-born people are living in a county and three more move there, that's a 100% increase!  What is happening around where you are from and why do you think that might be?

name: Santiago
comment info: I notice that in 1921 when congress imposed national-origin quotas, it started decreasing. It went from 15% to 5 %. But when president Lyndon B. terminated it, it started rising again and now it's at 13.6%. I also noticed that in Asia, the foreign-born population is increasing a lot faster than the European because before the quotas ended, they were practically at the same percentage. I think that in about 10-15 years, the foreign-born baby's are going to be at the highest percentage in history.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Santiago. It is interesting to wonder if the graph will keep rising in the next 10-15 years. Have you tuned into any policy conversations that are happening in the U.S. right now that might impact that?

You said that when the quotas ended, two things were at almost the same percentage.  Could you say more about that?  I'm not entirely sure what you are comparing and want to understand it.  It is for sure true that the European portion isn't increasing as fast as other origins!

name: Anthony
comment info: i noticed that the percent of foreign born increased and decreased with changes in policies that government made. I wonder why they need changes.

name: Renata AOSE
comment info: In this graph I notice that before 1921, when Congress passed and later enforced the national-origin quotas, the percentage of immigrants from Europe was at its highest (close to 15% 1980-1910) and slowly began to decrease following the quotas (lowest during the 2000s at around 1.5%). I also notice that after Lyndon B. Johnson ended quotas based on national origin, the percentage of Asian and Latin American immigrants outnumbered the percentage of European immigrants (Latin America at around 7% and Asia around 4.2% in the 2000s). I wonder how the different legislations brought about such a significant change? Perhaps the reason for this could be that the quota system decreased the amount of immigrants allowed to come into the country. Once it was lifted, there was a surge in immigration to the US again leading to more foreign-born. Possible Title:"Immigration Nation: Percentages of the Foreign-Born from 1880 to the 2000s."

replies.comment info: Hi, @Renata AOSE.  The top graph does make me want to learn more about those immigration policies! I wonder if you did any thinking about the county map. There is a lot of fascinating stuff in there as well.

name: Tera B.
comment info: I noticed that that in 1880 to roughly 1970 there was a drastic difference in the amount of European foreign-born share of the population and the amount of Asian, Latin American, and other foreign-born shares of the population. The number of European people was so much larger than any other race. Then when President Johnson ended quotas based on national origin in 1965, there was a huge increase in Asian and Latin American foreign-born people, while the European foreign-born population went down and the other foreign-born population stayed roughly the same. I wonder why there was such a large decrease in the European foreign-born population.  A good title for the graph and the map is "The different backgrounds of the American People".

name: Allison Coble
comment info:
What I first noticed when I looked at this graph is the valley-like structure of the graph forming the steady decrease, later morphing into a large increase years later. This is due to the fluctuating restrictions which were put in place in 1921 and were ended in 1965 creating an unsteady imbalance throughout the graph.

The second thing I noticed was that the European population was very large from the 1880s and then leveling out in the 1970s. But I wonder why it flattened out so quickly in the 2000s? Could they have increased after the year 2000s and it just took them longer to increase? I am also very interested in what the graph would look like after the 2000’s or maybe before the 1880’s?

Headline: Foreign-born populations in the US

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Allison Coble I like how you point out the different features and trends of the graph. What are some possible reasons as to why immigration to the US has changed over time?

name: Emily
comment info:
I notice. . . Many of the areas on the map that have a lot of immigrants are in the Southern part of the country, which makes sense because it is close to Latin America. And in the beginning of the national quota graph, the levels of European immigration were far greater than the levels of Asian or Latin American immigration. They peaked in 1910 and have been falling ever since.

I wonder. . . If we have immigrants from Europe and Asia too, why does the Northern part of our country not have as many immigrants? Is this because we have the most levels if immigration from Latin America? Also, based on the first graph, why did the amount of foreign-born citizens from Latin America and Asia increase a lot after 1965, while the European rates of immigration were still steadily dropping?

My headline: The Ebb and Flow of Foreign Immigration

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Emily --

You may answer some of your wonderings after you take another look at the titles on the graph and map.  Do they show number of foreign born or something else?  

Percentages are tricky.  Both the number of foreign born and the number of total population could change – increase or decrease.  Also, for small counties, only a few additional foreign born could greatly change the percentage.  And, conversely, for large cities, it would take many more foreign born to change their percentage by the same amount.   

With your additional insights, what would you say about why the South is dark green (increase in percentage change in foreign-born share of population by county)?

replies.name: S
replies.comment info:
@Emily 
It is an interesting point that you brought up the area that the types of immigrants were in! I did not think of this, but it is a very interesting way to look at the data and a good observation.

I also notice that it shows the number of immigrants in the US. I wonder why is it that it's not continuous and if it has changed until 2020.

replies.name: G
replies.comment info: @Barbara (ASFG) Good points! Regarding the first graph, what do you think/notice about the effect of national-origin quotas of the rates of immigration?

name: Tyler
comment info: -This graph shows the amount of foreign-born people in the U.S. population. It was around 12-15% between 1880 and 1910 until congress imposed national-origin quotas in 1921. From then until 1965 the number decreased to around 5%. Quotas were ended in 1965 and the numbers increased to 13.6% by the end of 2017.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Tyler --

Thank you for your noticings.  The graphs show the percentage share of foreign born for the U. S. population and not the number.  It’s even possible to have an increase in percentage share but a decrease in number of foreign born.  

You can see a comparison of the percentage and number for the entire country here:https://www.census.gov/newsroom/pdf/cspan_fb_slides.pdf.  With a little more searching, I bet you could find the percentage and number by state.

name: Devyn D
comment info: I noticed that in the top graph that once Johnson lifted the quota restriction on immigrants, that the foreign-born percentage of the population skyrocketed. I wonder why in the second graph, most of the foreign-born population lives in the south-east. A possible title could be “Filling the American Melting Pot.”

replies.comment info:
HI, @Devyn D --

Very good question:  “Why in the second graph, most of the foreign-born population lives in the south-east.”  

Is it most of the foreign born lives there or, as you write, the percentage increase is greater?  Now, think why this could be happening.  There are many reasons including a mathematical reason.  For a given increase in the number of foreign born, is the percentage change greatest for the most or least populous counties?  Or, to say it another way, if 100 foreign born come to a rural county will it increase the percentage of foreign born more or less than if they come to a city?  Please report back to us with your thinking.

name: Avery Hodges
comment info:
Looking at this graph, I notice two things. First, when Congress imposed national-origin quotas, the percentage heavily decreased, and second, when Lyndon B. Johnson ended the quotas, it spikes back up. As you can see, without the quotas in place, the population of Europeans decreases, and Asians and Latin Americans increase.

I wonder what the graph would look like today, since it ends at the year 2000, and I wonder how much different the population is.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Avery Hodges --

Take another look at the sources for the graph.  When does the data end?  I, too, would like to know what the data is for foreign born through the present.  I bet you can find it with a search online.  
Be careful of the differences in changes in number and changes in percentage.  For example, the percentage of Europeans can decrease while the number are increasing.

name: Abby AOSE
comment info:
Headline: Population Foreign-Born Share in the US

I notice that the population of the foreign-born share was the highest in 1890-1910, at about 15%. Most of this 15 % were foreign-born people from Europe. However, in 1921 Congress put a national-origin quote in place, and ever since that was passed the population drastically decreased. The population started to increase back up to 15% after Johnson ended the quotas based on national origin in 1965. Therefore, he reverted back to the original ways as soon as Johnson removed what Congress had set up. Without the quota, the population of Europeans decreased and the population of Asian and Latin American peoples has increased. 

I wonder what this graph would look like now in 2020. Why did the quota and the removal of it have such a great effect on the population? What are some factors that could have led to a drastic decrease in the European population over the time of this graph?

replies.name: A
replies.comment info: @Abby AOSE I'm also curious as to what this graph would look like in the present day, given all the factors that are included such as tighter immigration restrictions, etc. What do you think the percentages would look like?

HI, @Abby AOSE --

You’re asking a lot of great questions.  With immigration legislation, “the devil is in the details.”  

The impact of the 1921 Emergency Quota Act, the Immigration Act of 1924, and the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965 have quotas and formulas for admitting foreign born.  By looking at the details, you can uncover some of the reasons for the amount of immigration by region.

name: Erin S
comment info:
I notice that the national-origin quotas had a large effect on the percentage of foreign-born share of the population. Before the quota was implemented in 1921, the average percentage was around 15%. From 1921 to 1965, the percentage decrease, yet began to rise back to 15% after it was terminated.
I also noticed that this quota disproportionately affected immigrants from Latin America and Asia over those from Europe. When the quota was abolished, the percentage of Asian and Latin American immigrants significantly increased while the percentage European immigrants continued to decline.
I wonder what the map would look like if it were based on the change in the number of immigrants instead of the percentages of the county's population. Since this map is using percentages of the entire county's population, larger cities will usually have a smaller percent change than smaller, rural cities.
"The History and Dispersion of Foreign-born Groups in America"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Erin S --

Exactly!  “Since this map is using percentages of the entire county's population, larger cities will usually have a smaller percent change than smaller, rural cities.”  You may want to explain why this happens.  

Alternatively, with percentage change by county, counties with few foreign born, which may typically be rural counties, can have large percentage changes for very few additional immigrants.

What do you think is the most effective way to reflect changes in foreign born by county?

name: Moderator
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  
Today’s graph and map show American immigrants’ share of the population.  What is insightful is seeing how immigration has changed over time by country of origin and by U.S. county of residence.
From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph and the map. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these visual representations and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.
Note that you can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  
“What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be releasing graphs through May 20.  The next graph will be released in two days – Friday, May 8 with moderation on Wednesday, May 13.  The graph – coronavirus vaccines.  Stay tuned.

The impact of the 1921 Emergency Quota Act, the Immigration Act of 1924, and the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965 have quotas and formulas for admitting foreign born.  By looking at the details, you can uncover some of the reasons for the amount of immigration by region.

name: Caroline Martin
comment info:
In this graph, I notice that the percentage of foreign population has risen and fallen below 15% since 1880. I also notice that after the foreign percentage picked back up around the 1970's, European immigration has continued to fall, while both Asian and Latin American immigrants have increased. I was surprised to see that the percentage of immigrants in the U.S. is so low..

After Congress imposed the national-origin quotas, the foreign population fell to just above 5%. I wonder why, although Lyndon B. Johnson ended the quotas 44 years later, the lowest foreign population percentage did not seem to occur until ~50 years later. I also wonder if the percentage has fallen since 2017, as the current administration works to prevent immigration. 

In this graph, we see the percentage of foreign population in the U.S. dip  substantially and then rise once again. In a way, (and I'm not exactly sure why) it kind of reminds me of an underdog team as it becomes the champion.  I might title this graph: "The Rise of the Underdog."

replies.comment info:
HI, @Caroline Martin --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.  
Please explain to us your wonder: “(W)hy, although Lyndon B. Johnson ended the quotas 44 years later, the lowest foreign population percentage did not seem to occur until ~50 years later.”  Where do you see the evidence of this?
Who do you think is the “underdog?”  And, why do you think the underdog is rising?

name: Viola
comment info:
-I noticed that in recent years there has been an increase in the Latin immigrant population and a decrease in the European immigrant population. I also noticed that the areas on the map with a more dense immigrant population (possibly cities) often neighbor areas with very low immigrant populations (possibly the cities suburbs). 
-I wonder why there is a greater populations of immigrants on the east coast as opposed to the west coast.
-"The Foreign Born Population in the United States has Shifted Greatly Over Time"

replies.comment info:
HI, @Viola --

Take care to note the difference between a population change and a percentage change.  Both of these graphics use percentage change.  For example, you say “I wonder why there is a greater population of immigrants on the east coast as opposed to the west coast.”  This is a percentage change, not a population change.  A percentage of foreign born can increase because there is an increase in the number of foreign born or a decrease in total population.  Also, for a given increase in foreign born, this will represent a smaller increase if the total population is greater.  Maybe that is why we don’t see a big percentage increase in cities like LA and NYC.  

I searched online for foreign born in Ohio.  I was very surprised that its percentage of the total population is less than the national average.  Does that surprise you, too?

name: Jocelyn
comment info: I noticed that there has been a decrease in the number of European immigrants, while there has been an increase in Latin and Asian immigrants. I am curious as to what factors go into this increase and decrease. A good headline would be, Foreign-born numbers, increasing or decreasing?

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Jocelyn a factor might be immigration bans.

name: Cameron D
comment info: I noticed that the European immigrants went down while Latin american immigrants went up tremendously after the quotas were removed. I wonder why the European immigrant population went down so drastically.

I also notice that It is less likely for immigrants to populate the west coast. I wonder why the amount of European immigrants went down after the 40's. I think it probably had something to do with job opportunities.

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: @Martha Why do you think it is less likely for immigrants to populate the west coast?

name: Rebekah
comment info: I noticed that there has been an increase of Latin and Asian immigrants and a decrease of European immigrants. I also noticed that less foreign people populated the west coast than anywhere else. I wonder why this is.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Rebekah --

Take another look at the graph and map.  Does it show the number of foreign born or something else?  You could find online the number of foreign born by region and see if the pattern of these data is the same as the percentage change.

name: Vianca
comment info: I notice that over the years there has been a decrease of European immigrants and an increase in Latin and Asian immigrants. I also noticed that there is more of a foreign-born population in the mid-west, south, and east coast. I wonder why there was a large decline in European immigrants. I think more foreign people populated the mid-west and east coast because there were more job opportunities there.

name: Sarah
comment info:
Headline: US Population from the Foreign-born
I noticed that foreign people who were born in their country move more to the eastern coast of the United States.
I wonder why immigration dropped after President Johnson stopped making quotas in 1965.

name: Lydia
comment info: I noticed that over time the European population decreased while Latin American and asian groups increase over time. I think that the quota that congress imposed in 1921 had an effect on the types of groups coming into the U.S. resulting in a large amount of europeans coming in during the 1910s and 1920s and after President Johnson ended the quota we see an increase in other groups who probably weren't able to move to the U.S. due to the quota. In recent years you can also see that foreign born people are moving to the eastern part of the U.S. probably due large cities and more readily available jobs there as well as a more diverse population.

name: Barbara Anderson
comment info:
Responses of Gabi Vaculin and Jackson Sander

We noticed that there were many Europeans who came to America in the late 1800's until 1929. Then Congress imposed quotas and the Great Depression happened and fewer Europeans came.​

We also noticed that recently, the foreign-born people move more to the eastern part of the US. We think this might be because there are more jobs in the bigger cities.

We wonder why after President Johnson stopped the quotas the level of European immigration dropped while Latin American and Asian increased.​

Title-
Foregin-Born Share of US Population- Ups and Downs​

replies.comment info:
HI, Gabi Vaculin and Jackson Sander of @Barbara Anderson class --

Thank you for your noticings and wonderings.  Take another look at the map.  Which regions have the greatest percentage change in foreign-born share of the population by county?  When you notice about the percentage change, take into account the total populations of the counties.  For a given increase in the number of foreign born, is the percentage change greatest for the most or least populous counties?  Or, to say it another way, if 100 foreign born come to a rural county will it increase the percentage of foreign born more or less than if they come to a city?  Please report back to us with your thinking.

name: Maureen Fonken
comment info:
As a teacher, I'd really appreciate it if you would not advertise on pages meant to be shared as assignments with students. 

If you want to provide this service, I think that's great, but please don't direct your marketing to students just trying to get an education.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Maureen Fonken Thank you for letting us know. Ads are supposed to be removed from The Learning Network. I've made a request to find out why ads are sometimes appearing. Hopefully the issue will be resolved quickly. Sometimes readers see things that we don't see, so it's always helpful when you let us know about things like this. You can also reach us atLNFeedback@nytimes.com.
